What is 'rigging'

When animating something for a game, you use an armature(also called skeleton, a collection of bones). This makes animating much easier as you just have to animate the bones and not per vertex or face individually. The bones act just like their human counterpart, attached tissue moves with the bones. Which brings us to the downside, you have to attach the vertices to the bones, the mesh is then rigged to the armature.

Rigging in theory is very simple, you tell the computer how much each vertex is affected by each bone, these are called weights. When the vertices are attached they will automatically move, allowing the mesh to be positioned and animated simply by moving a couple of bones.

Important

Armatures are shared between different characters, so they can easily exchange animations and equipment. There for it's important you don't alter the armature, as that will make it a different armature.

Making the mesh

If you already have a mesh ready you can skip this step.

  • Creating basic chestarmor
  • Creating basic pants
  • Creating basic boots

Preparing the mesh

Before we get rigging, you'll need the armature for the character you're making this mesh for, you can get those here. Save it somewhere near your mesh file, you'll need to import it in a minute.

Open the armature's blend file and press SHIFT+F1 and locate the mesh file, open it, navigate to meshes, select your mesh and press 'Load library'.

Now position your mesh on the right location. Select your mesh then select the armature and press CTRL+P this will parent you mesh to the armature. The question "Make parent to" will pop-up, click on "Armature". The question "Create vertex groups?" will pop-up, click on "Don't create vertex groups".

Oke, now we should be ready for rigging.

Rigging the mesh

Checking if all vertices are rigged

Setting mesh type and properties

Exporting

Notes

When rigging an armor for a humanoid, the hardest part will be the shouders, you need to experiment a bit with the weights of the shoulder bones and arm bones. General advice is to give a small area a high weight, and the arms as little weight as possible, you want to shoulders to be rather steady when the arms hang besides the torso.

Things like pauldrons you want to give all weight to one bone, so it won't bend and look weird when animated.

Rigging isn't easy, so make sure you make regular copies of your file, before doing any big changes. As you might mess up your rig(which is likely on your first try :) )

Don't worry, practise makes perfect!
